title: AB 2676
content: Section 17052.6 of the Revenue and Taxation Code in California is amended to allow a credit against the "net tax" for expenses related to household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The credit amount is determined based on the Internal Revenue Code, with a percentage determined for taxable years before January 1, 2003. The adjusted gross income determines the percentage of credit for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment in California. The credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower or no credit. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of credit for household and dependent care services in California. Credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower or no credit. For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2019, the credit percentages are as follows: $100,000 or less - 200%, over $100,000 but not over $125,000 - 100%, over $125,000 but not over $150,000 - 50%, over $150,000 - 0%. Additionally, for incomes of $40,000 or less - 65% credit, over $40,000 but not over $70,000 - 50% credit, over $70,000 but not over $100,000 - 34% credit, over $100,000 - 0% credit. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of credit for household and dependent care services in California. Credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower or no credit. The credit is limited to expenses for household services and care provided in the state. Employment-related expenses for household and dependent care services in California are limited to services provided within the state. Earned income subject to tax in California includes compensation for active services in the Armed Forces. Qualifying individuals for the credit include children as defined in Section 152(f)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. For tax purposes in California, the definition of a qualifying child is modified to include age requirements as defined in Section 152(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. For tax purposes in California, a qualifying child must meet age requirements as defined in Section 152(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The child must receive over one-half of their support during the year from the parent with custody for a greater portion of the year, who is considered the "custodial parent" under Section 152(e). This classification allows the child to be treated as a qualifying individual under Section 21(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. The text discusses the criteria for a child to be considered a qualifying child for tax purposes in California, including receiving over one-half of their support from the custodial parent and being in their custody for more than one-half of the year. The amendments to the tax laws mentioned in the text apply to specific taxable years.
